Yes. Use method 'equilibriumConstants' defined in class 'Kinetics'.

Here's a Python example:

The script below produces the list of reaction equations and  
equilibrium constants following it.
Note that the equilibrium constants are in concentration units (if the  
mole numbers change in the reaction), and concentrations are in  
kmol/m^3.

------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
--
from Cantera import *

gas = GRI30()
gas.setTemperature(2000.0)

nrxns = gas.nReactions()
kc = gas.equilibriumConstants()
for i in range(nrxns):
     print '%5d  %30s  %g' % (i, gas.reactionEqn(i), kc[i])
------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
--

     0              2 O + M <=> O2 + M  3.67079e+08
     1            O + H + M <=> OH + M  8.48311e+07
     2               O + H2 <=> H + OH  1.36911
     3             O + HO2 <=> OH + O2  493047
     4           O + H2O2 <=> OH + HO2  221.569
     5               O + CH <=> H + CO  4.39328e+17
     6             O + CH2 <=> H + HCO  1.46015e+09
     7          O + CH2(S) <=> H2 + CO  3.15659e+19
     8          O + CH2(S) <=> H + HCO  3.01463e+10
     9            O + CH3 <=> H + CH2O  2.16153e+06
    10            O + CH4 <=> OH + CH3  26.9574
    11      O + CO (+ M) <=> CO2 (+ M)  1.85793e+08
    12             O + HCO <=> OH + CO  1.43358e+09
    13             O + HCO <=> H + CO2  3.13976e+09
    14           O + CH2O <=> OH + HCO  1197.71
    15         O + CH2OH <=> OH + CH2O  2.88605e+07
    16          O + CH3O <=> OH + CH2O  2.17362e+09
    17        O + CH3OH <=> OH + CH2OH  184.487
    18         O + CH3OH <=> OH + CH3O  2.44956
    19             O + C2H <=> CH + CO  3.09586e+08
    20           O + C2H2 <=> H + HCCO  174.215
    21           O + C2H2 <=> OH + C2H  0.0255761
    22           O + C2H2 <=> CO + CH2  1.66183e+06
    23          O + C2H3 <=> H + CH2CO  1.77717e+08
    24          O + C2H4 <=> CH3 + HCO  68177
    25         O + C2H5 <=> CH3 + CH2O  3.90803e+08
    26          O + C2H6 <=> OH + C2H5  201.356
    27           O + HCCO <=> H + 2 CO  2.35377e+14
    28         O + CH2CO <=> OH + HCCO  9.65758
    29         O + CH2CO <=> CH2 + CO2  201764
    30             O2 + CO <=> O + CO2  0.50614
    31         O2 + CH2O <=> HO2 + HCO  0.0024292
(list truncated)
